description.narrative: Spotlight regional programme seeks to enhance capacities of state and non-state actors in the countries of Central Asia and Afghanistan to prevent and respond to domestic and gender-based violence and harmful practices

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: Countries in the Central Asia region receive support to their efforts to tackle gender-based violence as part of post-pandemic recovery strategies and measures, including legislative action and strengthening of institutions, enhancing interaction between state and non-state actors to fill in the gaps and vital links in providing services and support to survivors of violence, and strengthening preventive action, including social norms challenging.

comment.narrative: In all six countries, the persistent and negative impact of gender norms remains one of the greatest barriers to ending all forms of SGBV and harmful practices. Survivors of SGBV hesitate to come forward due to limited trust in the police and judiciary to treat SGBV cases fairly; and fear of social stigma for leaving violent unions and making “family” matters public. Intersectionality of discrimination in Central Asia is a stark reality, with women in particular groups facing multiple layers of vulnerabilities to gender-based discrimination, including SGBV. These include women with disabilities, women living with HIV, rural women, ethnic minorities, women in early and/or forced marriage, and women migrants. Majority of legislative frameworks in the region do not align comprehensively with the international commitments, norms and standards outlined in the CEDAW and CRC Conventions, both of which all six countries have ratified; nor as outlined in the Beijing Platform for Action (BPfA) or the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). As regional studies on gender equality in the countries of Central Asia have shown, criminalization of domestic violence remains an open question in all five Central Asia countries, and that gender equality laws are also not universally adopted, nor effectively enforced in those countries where they have been adopted.

Limited scope of activities was planned for 2020 due to late approval of the regional programme and transfer of funds. The During the fourth quarter of 2020 it was planned to get the programme staff on board, complete inception and training sessions with the MPTF, Spotlight Secretariat and UNDP, plug into Spotlight COP community of practice learning, and formally launch the regional programme.
The formal launch of the Spotlight regional programme took place on 8 December 2020 as an-online event organised by UNDP, UNFPA, UN Women under overall coordination of the RC office.

Implement activities in support of the development of regional SOP models and tools for SGBV case referral and case management for police and justice sectors as part of multisectoral approach to service provision in coordination with UNFPA. Contribute to elaboration of model recommendations on strengthening of legislation on SGBV and harmful practices in the countries of the region in coordination with UN Women. Ensure broad engagement of civil society and community organisations and partnerships among stakeholders in providing multisectoral response to SGBV, services and gender sensitive decision making. Propose innovative models for collection of prevalence, administrative and perception data on SGBV and visualisation platform.

Under activity on Review of national legislation on sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV), a study of the architecture of SGBV response in 5 Central Asia (CA) countries was launched. Due to delays in procurement process major activities were shifted to December 2021– May 2022.
Under activity on National and cross-boarder networking strengthened for CA Alliance on SGBV, a series of meetings on police response to SGBV and exchange of country experiences conducted during the year, including regional on-line round table, study tour to Kazakhstan and regional virtual dialogue. Regional events were focused on organisation of specialized training for police, multi-sectoral response and coordination between police and other stakeholders providing services to the victims of violence and the role of specialized units for protection of women against violence. Aktobe Law Institute of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Kazakhstan and Police Academy of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Kyrgyzstan intend to sign a memorandum of cooperation on exchange of experience on response to domestic and sexual violence, joint research activities and exchange of trainers and experts.
Under the same component Grants Competition was conducted for the non-governmental organisations (NGOs) of 5 CA countries to identify organisations which have unique experience in working with victims of violence and defending their interests, and are able to arrange an exchange and knowledge transfer to interested partners as peer-to-peer. 10 NGOs selected of 30 grant applications, grants disbursed to 9 of selected organisations in Kazakhstan, Kyrgystan and Tajikistan. Uzbekistan is pending due to local financial regulation of NGO operations. Proposed applications offer a fair mix of advocacy, educational, direct support, and capacity-building experience, which can be documented and shared among peer NGOs. Each successful application has its clearly defined target group, including (rural/urban) women in difficult life situation, women in need of specialized social services, legal advice and other related services, youth and students, local communities, rural communities. These grant applications offer a variety of channels and means for the delivery of services, activities and advocacy information, including through printed materials, social media and TV and radio, information technilogy (IT) solutions. There are interesting examples of coordination mechanisms, engagement of local communities and self-governance entities in prevention and response to violence.
Under activity on Development of regional standard operating procedures (SOP) and tools for SGBV case referral and case management, a situational analysis of existing procedures, guidelines and policies available to police to manage SGBV cases is carried by the East European Institute for Reproductive Health. Simultaneously EEIRH conducts a study on availability of in-service/specialized training packages for police in 5 countries of CA. This work is closely coordinated with UNFPA component on SOPs and training for healthcare and social sectors. The results are to be presented at the regional level in April 2022.
Under activity on Regional Innovative Models for collecting and visualizing data on violence, a regional event is planned for students and recent graduates from 5 CA countries. Concept and TOR were developed in consultations with relevant stakeholders, including UNDP Accelerator Labs. UNDP is organizing an on-line IT Against GBV Hackathon regional event. It seeks to bring together students, recent graduates and experts on gender equality and EVAW in a collective effort to explore the potential of digital technologies in prevention of violence and generating data on violence, while acknowledging new threats and forms of violence brought by digital technologies.
